body.body: Generate adequate background information on the use of insecticide on fields through, Knowledge-Attitude-Practice \(KAP) surveys \(Yadouleton et al. 2009) in the study site.
At the time of the survey, apprise the farmers on the aim of the study. Interviews may be conducted in local language and preferably, a verbal consent is to be taken from all the participants.

The survey is to be conducted through direct observations, in-depth interviews with the individual farmers using a semi-structured questionnaire to gather information on various aspects of cropping pattern and pesticide usage i.e. type, frequency, the dosage of the insecticides in the study site.
Select a study site of field crops \(cotton, brinjal or any other host plants of B. tabaci) and record the exact GPS coordinates of the collection sites.
While collecting, walk in ‘Z’ mode at a minimum of two-hectare blocks of the crops.
Insects are to be collected using an aspirator during early morning along with infested leaves containing the nymphs and pupae \(Fig. 2).
The insects are to be transported to the laboratory in ventilated cages containing leaflets inserted into wet sponges.
Infested leaflets are to be kept in cages for the emergence of fresh adults.
The taxonomic identity of B. tabaci is to be confirmed by examining the instar under a light microscope using the keys of Martin \(1987) and Chaubey et al. \(2015).

These populations have to be raised in a separately ventilated acrylic cages \(45cm x 45cm x 45cm) on insecticide-free cotton plants \(Gossypium hirsutum) at temperatures of 27 ± 2°C, photoperiod of 14:10 h \(Light: Dark) and relative humidity of 60–70% in insect growth chambers.
The insect populations are to be maintained as large colonies for five generations without exposure to insecticide and to be used for a further test.

title: **C. Determination of genetic group status of _B. tabaci_**

body.body: The genetic group identity of B. tabaci field populations is to be examined by random sampling of 10 adults for each population.
DNA may be extracted from single adult females using DNeasy Blood and Tissue Kit \(Qiagen GmbH, Hilden, Germany) or by using any other DNA extraction kits.

Partial mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase 1 \(mtCO1) gene is to be amplified by polymerase chain reaction \(PCR) using forward primer CI–J–2195 \(3'–TTGATTTTTTGGTCATCCAGAAGT–5') and in combination with a reverse primer TL2–N–3014 \(3'–TCCAATGCACTAATCTGCCATATTA–5').

25 μL PCR reactions are to be carried out with the PCR mix containing 2.0 μL template DNA, 2.0 μL of each primer \(5 pmol/ uL), 12.5 μL of Dream Taq Green Master Mix \(2X) \(Thermo Scientific Co., USA), 8.5 μL of nuclease free water \(Thermo Scientific Co., USA). The annealing temperature was 50 °C for primers of mtCO1.
The PCR amplicons \(~750bp) are to be sequenced through Sanger’s sequencing by outsourcing.
The genetic group can be determined by direct sequence comparisons using the web-based Basic Local Alignment Search Tool algorithm of NCBI \(https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi).

The genetic group identity can further be confirmed by the phylogenetic and molecular evolutionary analysis with well-assigned and update homologous sequences of the _B. tabaci_ genetic groups from the consensus sequence database \(De Barro et al., 2011).

During the phylogenetic and molecular evolutionary analysis, the sequences were edited and aligned using MUSCLE programme with default parameters. The best substitution model was determined using jModelTest v0.1.1. Phylogenetic trees were constructed using maximum likelihood with 1000 bootstrap reiterations using MEGA v6.0.
Autoclave the deionized water, glass vials, and forceps.
Ventilate the disposable sterile Petri plate lids with small holes with a diameter of 1mm by using insect pin #
Procure the technical grade of insecticide compounds to be tested from the manufacturers or dealers of the chemicals.
Prepare the desired stock solutions of the purity analyzed technical grade insecticides in acetone.
Prepare all desired concentrations required for the treatments from the original stock solution using autoclaved deionized water containing 0.1g L–1 of non-ionic wetting agent Triton X-100.
Collect cotton leaves with petiole from the pot culture grown plants not exposed to insecticides.

The leaves are to be collected from fifteen to twenty-five days old seedlings and washed with deionized water.
  


_II. Conducting Bioassays_
Prepare agar solutions by mixing 2% w/w agar powder with autoclaved deionized water and boil until all agar is melted.
Allow the melted agar for cooling for 10 m.
Place the Petri plates on a laboratory table in slanting mode and pour approximately 10 ml of warm agar into each Petri plate.

Immerse the cotton leaves with petiole into the serially diluted insecticide solutions for 20 s and after treatment, allow the leaves to air dry on paper towels. Cotton leaves dipped in only diluents serve as an untreated control.

Once the agar slant in the Petri plates has cooled down and set, insert the treated leaf petiole into the agar slant using forceps. Prior to insertion into the agar slant, make a staggered cut at the tip of the petiole by a razor blade.
Collect the insects for testing using an aspirator.
The adult whiteflies are to be anesthetized using CO2 for 10-15 seconds and transfer about 20 insects onto the treated leaves and seal the plates with ventilated lids \(Fig. 3).
When the whiteflies have recovered from CO2 narcosis and allow orienting normally at the downside of the leaf.
The bioassays are to be replicated five times for a minimum of five concentrations for each insecticide.
All the treatment plates have to be placed in an insect rearing room at temperatures of 27 ± 2°C, photoperiod of 14:10 h \(Light: Dark) and relative humidity of 60–70%.
The adult insects are to be considered to be dead if it shows no coordinated movement or deficient in response when gently probed with a fine paint brush.
Mortality is to be estimated by counting the total number of dead and live insects at 24/48/72/96 h after treatment.
The mortality data is to be corrected according to Abbott’s formula \(Abbott, 1925).

The LC50 and LC90 values, 95% confidence limits, standard errors, the slopes of the regression lines and χ2 significance tests, can be estimated by probit analysis \(Finney, 1947). A number of software programs are available for probit analysis \(for example, one can use PoloPlus 2.0 software, LeOra Software, California, United States).
